Table.Industry / Model: Healthcare services that meet real needs (home health, ABA therapy, PT/OT/speech, dermatology, optometry, audiology)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "If it's a great business that happens to be in healthcare, I think it's a huge win." "Healing others is the highest calling." "I would happily pay 5x for that."
Table.Notes / caveats: ABA remains top interest, but excitement in Arizona is tempered by Medicaid risk. Current ABA/HCBS target is 75% HCBS/25% ABA with ~96% Medicaid; likely AZ rate cuts make him cautious and he may walk unless a large standby/forgivable seller note shifts policy risk. Prefers pure-play ABA with a balanced payer mix and stronger rates (for example, SoCal Medi‑Cal clinics have much higher reimbursement). Local Phoenix is ideal. Wants recurring demand, low concentration, clear DSCR, and to avoid heavy Medicaid at‑home mix unless protected. Mid‑January 2026: said he is "mentally checked out" on the current AZ target; the state moved to dismiss the Centria v. MercyCare case; he will push a re‑trade and set an end‑of‑January go/no‑go.

Table.Industry / Model: IT Managed Service Providers and cybersecurity services
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "MSPs are sticky… I know the industry kind of intimately." "Unfair advantage." Also sees cyber "only going to blow up." Called a healthcare IT + MSP deal "super cool." "Much closer fit with my background."
Table.Notes / caveats: LOI fully signed (early Jan 2026) on a healthcare IT + MSP. Seeks contracted revenue and channel familiarity. Avoids heavy paid ads. Prefers low capex, steady renewals. Cautiously optimistic; notes it may be "buying a job" for 12–24 months, but the seller will stay 2–3 years and there is a growth roadmap. He said, "VARs are in a weird contracting middle ground… I’m not looking to overpay for a VAR. What I really want is a solid platform MSP." He also called the space "cutthroat," so he will favor sticky MRR and platform MSPs over pure resellers. After meeting the seller, he said the business is very owner‑dependent and "he does three people's jobs"; Pushkar is on the fence unless he can hire near‑shore support fast and use working capital to fund 1–2 early hires. He is "not excited" to be the only one handling tickets for 2–3 years. Likes hosted PBX recurring and an agentic‑AI after‑hours cross‑sell; small colo/server capex is fine. Lender outreach queued. Phoenix first; open to SoCal if stand‑out.

Table.Industry / Model: HVAC service and maintenance (esp. Phoenix and commercial)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "If your air conditioning is not working, there is no higher necessity than that."
Table.Notes / caveats: Licensed trade. He is "up for the challenge" and sees licensing as a moat. Needs a compliant qualifier plan until he earns his own license; learned his engineering degree counts toward required experience and expects about two years of qualifier support. Prefers strong service contract base and predictable DSCR. Avoids heavy new‑construction exposure and bid‑only work.

Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "Pretty much everything on this list is a necessity… the willingness to pay is very high."
Table.Notes / caveats: Wants strong safety, staffing, and compliance. Prefers established centers with steady enrollment and low seasonality. Local Phoenix market preferred.

Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "Everyone dies." Clear need and recurring nature appealed to him.
Table.Notes / caveats: Prior transport deal was not SBA‑able and all‑cash, so he passed. Seeks SBA‑fit and steady, respectful operators with low concentration.

Table.Industry / Model: Light manufacturing with mandated replacement cycles (for example, traffic signs, certain safety or compliance products)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "Each sign needs to have a specific amount of reflectivity… every two or three years a sign wears out." "That’s such a great business."
Table.Notes / caveats: Likes B2B recurring or replacement cycles and simple operations. Will avoid overpriced real estate tied to the deal. Prefers Phoenix; will not relocate for weak CRE math.

Table.Industry / Model: Commercial landscaping and property services (year‑round maintenance in Phoenix)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "Out here you need landscaping pretty much 12 months out of the year. Commercial landscaping, even better."
Table.Notes / caveats: Favors contract maintenance over one‑off projects. Wants route density, low concentration, and dependable crews.

Table.Industry / Model: Med spa injectables and selected cash‑pay clinical aesthetics (Botox; consider LASIK)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "Botox is really sticky… it becomes a critical thing that you have to keep getting." On Scottsdale: "100% open."
Table.Notes / caveats: Focus on sticky services and financing models that keep retention high. Avoid purely cosmetic fads. Scottsdale is attractive given demand. Wants proven DSCR and trained staff.

Table.Industry / Model: Plumbing and other needs‑based trades with maintenance plans (garage doors, elevators, roofing with inspections)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "When your bathroom is flooding, you need a plumber." On roofing after learning about maintenance subs and drones: "100% open."
Table.Notes / caveats: Licensed trade items may need qualifier coverage. Seeks maintenance programs and commercial contracts, not only one‑off installs. Avoids new‑construction‑heavy revenue.

Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "I have an open mind… could be CapEx heavy… but it’s also needed." "B2B logistics is great." Capex heavy "but that’s also a moat."
Table.Notes / caveats: Will accept capex if contracts and utilization are strong. Wants low customer concentration and predictable cash flow.

Table.Industry / Model: Pet services (grooming, daycare/boarding, training, vet support)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): Sees many pet services as essential for owners; he is a pet owner himself.
Table.Notes / caveats: Prefers contracted or membership revenue and steady demand. Local Phoenix demand is strong. Avoids high retail inventory models.

Table.Industry / Model: B2B digital services that help businesses win (SEO, web development, banner/sign printing)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): Open because they sell to businesses and can be recurring. Notes AI creates new upsell paths.
Table.Notes / caveats: Cautious about performance marketing. Wants existing book of business, not a paid‑ads treadmill. Prefers contracts and repeat work.

Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "If your car breaks down, you need to get it fixed." Likes clear need vs want.
Table.Notes / caveats: Dislikes rentals and dealer models. Prefers service and replacement demand with repeat customers. Local route density is a plus.

Table.Industry / Model: Niche B2B SaaS if reasonably priced and sticky
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): "If you find a good SaaS business with a reasonable multiple, man, that’s 100% in my wheelhouse."
Table.Notes / caveats: Strong fit to his background. Only if multiples are reasonable, churn is low, and it is B2B sticky. Avoids models reliant on Google or paid traffic. Recent SaaS target went quiet; still open if price and stickiness are right.

Table.Industry / Model: Waste and remediation services (junk removal, mold removal, select environmental cleanups)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): He labeled these as clear needs with steady demand.
Table.Notes / caveats: Prefers scheduled, repeatable work with contract customers and low seasonality. Avoids heavy regulatory burden without strong moats and margins.

Table.Industry / Model: Pool services in Phoenix (service and maintenance)
Table.Why client is excited (quote/summary): Recognizes steady need year‑round and common outsourcing by homeowners.
Table.Notes / caveats: Wants route density, quality control, and low churn. Notes operator quality matters. Prefers contract base over only one‑time cleans.
